nodes.bodyText: while discussion is not finished on how to deal with this Checks, lets keep them as they were on  "Regular Expression" (not real java type), See details in telegram group.

as we already have such type "Regular Expressions" in doc, we will keep it and even place in metadata for now, to let plugins know that type is very special and specified in words only in chekcstyle doc.
same here, why it is an exception/
while discussion is not finished on how to deal with this Checks, lets keep them as they were on  "Regular Expression" (not real java type), See details in telegram group.

I would suggest to move these sorting changes to new PR to not mix it with renaming changes. Also, please add screenshot or list how new order looks like (to make sure it is sorted properly, it is not clear from diff)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -908,56 +927,52 @@ -
+

- This type represents policy on placement of the Javadoc content. + This type represents a URI. The string representation is parsed using a custom + routine to analyze what type of URI the string is. + It can be a URL, regular file, or a resource path. It will try loading the path as + a URL first, then as a file that must exist, and then finally as a resource on the + classpath. +

+
+ +
+

+ This type represents the policy for wrapping lines. The following table describes the valid options:

- +
- - + - - +
Option Definition
FIRST_LINEnl - Represents the policy for Javadoc content starts from the same line - as /**. - Example: + The token must be on a new line. For example: 
-            /** Summary text.
-              * More details.
-              */
-            public void method();
+    someVariable = aBigVariableNameToMakeThings + "this may work"
+                   + lookVeryInteresting;
- This style is also known as "scala" style.
SECOND_LINEeol - Represents the policy for Javadoc content starts from the next line - after /**. - Example: + The token must be at the end of the line. For example: 
-              /**
-              * Summary text.
-              * More details.
-              */
-              public void method();
+    someVariable = aBigVariableNameToMakeThings + "this may work" +
+                   lookVeryInteresting;

nodes.bodyText:
checkstyle/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/metrics/AbstractClassCouplingCheck.java
    
    
         Line 152
      in
      cf08aa0
    
    
    
    

        
          
           public void setExcludeClassesRegexps(String... from) { 
        
    
  


it is String[] in setter, so  real type is String[], if we want  to mean regexp nature of it keep it Regular Expressions.
Please do the same by all others.
PLEASE keep in this PR only updates where setter type is Pattern, all other cases keep as  Regular Expression or  Regular Expressions`.
nodes.diffHunk: @@ -696,7 +696,7 @@ class Foo { excludeClassesRegexps Specify user-configured regular expressions to ignore classes. - Regular Expressions + Pattern[]

nodes.bodyText:
@romani
That is what I tried to mention here in my comment #8328 (comment) that there are more than 5 such cases where setter type and field class is different.
excludeClasses have field type List<Pattern> . So these types didn't pop up in @rnveach's list #8328 (comment). I will then generate such occurences and omit them too.
Updated List of such occurences: #8328 (comment)
